sn54.6:1.3: “Mendicants, do you develop mindfulness of breathing?”
sn54.6:1.4: When he said this, Venerable Ariṭṭha said to him:
sn54.6:1.6: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”
sn54.6:1.7: “Sir, I’ve given up desire for sensual pleasures of the past. I’m rid of desire for sensual pleasures of the future. And I have eliminated perception of repulsion regarding phenomena internally and externally.
sn54.6:1.8: Just mindful, I will breathe in. Mindful, I will breathe out.
sn54.6:1.9: That’s how I develop mindfulness of breathing.”
sn54.6:2.1: “That is mindfulness of breathing, Ariṭṭha; I don’t deny it.
sn54.6:2.2: But as to how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail,
sn54.6:2.3: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
sn54.6:3.1: “And how is mindfulness of breathing fulfilled in detail?
sn54.6:3.2: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in front of them.
sn54.6:3.3: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
sn54.6:3.4: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ …
sn54.6:3.5: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.6:3.6: This is how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail.”
